title: Spanish Bishop on Maya Societies SAQ2

content.description:
“The Maya nobles agreed that the royal family of Cocoms should have the royal power.1Maya kings in the Yucatan were typically appointed by a council of nobles and exercised authority over a number of cities within the region. After they agreed to this, since within the central areas of the major cities there were only temples and houses for the nobles and the high priest, they ordered that other houses should be constructed outside those areas for the peasants. Each noble then appointed an officer to manage the financial affairs of the towns and to provide goods to the nobles when needed.

The nobles then appointed governors, whose sons often succeeded them, and were responsible for supporting the poor and maintaining the peace of the town. The priests got their living from their offices and from offerings. The nobles governed the town, settling disputes, and managing the affairs of the Maya republics, all of which was done with the help of their officials who were well obeyed and highly esteemed.”

Published account of Maya society written by the Spanish archbishop of the Yucatan region of Mexico, 1566
